Robert Sayre wrote:
> On 6/28/07, John Panzer <jpanzer@...> wrote:
> 
>>  Both Content-Range and PATCH need to define infoset-level extensions.
>>Content-Range might possibly be dropped silently by very broken intermediaries,
>>but PATCH is known to be blocked by some proxies in certain configurations (e.g.,
>>Squid).  I don't see a clear winner.
> 
> 
> That's inaccurate. First, Content-Range is known to be ignored by
> *origin servers*. 

Again, not relevant to a discussion about new extensions to be 
implemented by servers on an opt-in basis with a discovery mechanism.

> Second, I wonder how many proxies block PATCH, but
> not PUT. I know there are several that explicitly block PROPFIND, etc.

Any proxy that blocks PUT also blocks AtomPub of course (my main use case).

> because Microsoft security bugs. There are also several that block
> everything except for GET, POST, and HEAD. If you really want to
> tunnel around obnoxious proxies, just add an X-No-Really: header to
> POST requests. This would work on TMobile USA, for instance, but PUT
> with Content-Range would not. Or use HTTPS, which is impervious to
> proxies.

I suspect all of these solutions will likely be using HTTPS anyway.

> 
> There are several choices that don't require broken standards.
> Transparency is a good thing. There is a trade-off, in that cheap and
> obvious request routing is more prone to proxy meddling on insecure
> channels. Who desperately needs to deploy insecure PUT requests on a
> massive scale?
>
